title: Iran Warns of 'Decisive Response' as Trump Sets 10-15 Day Deadline for Nuclear Deal
summary: Tensions escalate as Trump demands a deal within two weeks while Iran's UN envoy warns the Security Council that any military aggression will be met with force.
content:
The standoff between Washington and Tehran took a dangerous turn Thursday as President Trump set a hard deadline of 10 to 15 days for Iran to agree to a "meaningful" nuclear deal — while Iran's UN ambassador warned the Security Council that his country would respond "decisively" to any military aggression.

Speaking at the inaugural meeting of his Board of Peace in Washington, Trump delivered the ultimatum with characteristic bluntness: "Maybe we're going to make a deal. You're going to be finding out over the next probably 10 days."

Asked to elaborate aboard Air Force One, he added: "I would think that would be enough time, 10, 15 days, pretty much, maximum."

>> "Otherwise, bad things happen." — Donald Trump

## Iran Pushes Back

Iran's UN ambassador Amir Saeid Iravani responded with a letter to the Security Council urging international condemnation of Trump's threats. He specifically cited Trump's recent mention of using an airfield in the Chagos Islands as a staging point for potential strikes on Iran.

"Such a belligerent statement by the President of the United States must not be treated as mere rhetoric," Iravani wrote, noting that the ongoing US military buildup in the region gives the words operational weight.

Iran emphasized it "neither seeks tension nor war and will not initiate any war" — but warned that if attacked, it would consider "all bases, facilities, and assets of the hostile force" in the region as legitimate targets.

## Progress vs. Posturing

The escalation is jarring because it follows what both sides described as productive indirect talks just days ago. Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said last Wednesday that "good progress" had been made in negotiations.

Trump's gambit appears calculated — create a public deadline to force urgency while keeping the military threat credible. It's the same playbook he used with North Korea in his first term, to mixed results.

But Iran in 2026 is a different adversary. The joint US-Israeli strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities last June fundamentally changed the calculus. Iran has been rebuilding and hardening its defenses. The stakes of military action are dramatically higher than they were even a year ago.

## The Next Two Weeks

The world is now watching a very public countdown. Either a deal framework emerges — likely involving nuclear enrichment limits in exchange for sanctions relief — or the situation escalates toward what could be the most consequential military confrontation of the decade.

The smart money says this is brinksmanship, not a prelude to war. But brinksmanship has a way of running away from the people practicing it.
